resources.string: This topic explores what happens as digits in a single number are swapped in a manner that generates different numbers from it. The idea of digital swapping is not focused on the value of the number, but on its digital array.

We will borrow from the rule of factorial, only this time addressing the number of digits and not the value of the number."

" 5! = 5 x 4 x 3 x 2 x 1 = 120"
" So generally, "
" n! = n x (n-1) x (n - 2) x (n-3)..."

" However, this time we will be taking a factorial, not of the value of the number, of the number of ways its digigts can be arranged. Ultimately, we will take pair by pair differences to observe if there is any pattern emerging."

"
Note:"
" The rule of factorial is only a way through, but thi topic is about taking differences between similar, but, swapped digits."

"
Example: 12 and 21"\n" As can be seen the two numbers have different values, however they do appear to be slit images of one another...."\n" Lazy to type again

Example: 31 - 13 = 18"
" 41-14 = 27"
"
Note that as the difference between the digits is plus or minus a number the outcome of which is a multiple of 9 and the absolute-value factor of which is the digital difference...."
" Lazy to type again"
"
The difference between any, digitally forward, and, digitally reverse, entries is a number the quotient by nine of which is some number the extreme digits are replicas of each other."\n"
The difference of any digital combination with its own, other, digital permmutation(s) is always a number divisible by 9."\n"
The nature of the repeating digit plus the digital absolute-value-difference of the actual difference in value, yield the nature of the consecutive repeat value"\n"

"Numbers the digits of which repeat or finitely recur, stem from the same digital nature.""
" "
" Example: "
" 12 + 21 = 33 "
" 23 + 32 = 55 "
" 123 + 321 = 444 "
"

CUBIC SUMS IN THE SUMS OF CUBES"

"
1^3 + 1^3 "
" 1 + 1"
" 2"
" ---------------------------------"
" (1 + 1)^3 "
" (2)^3"
" 8"

"
2^3 + 2^3 "
" 8 + 8"
" 16"
" ---------------------------------"
" (2 + 2)^3 "
" (4)^3"
" 64"
" ---------------------------------"

"
Thus,"
" (x + y)/( x3 + y )3 = 4"

"
For each pair above, divide the outcome of the second row by the outcome of the first row."
" That is, divide the result in the cubic sum by that in the sum of cubes:"
"
8/2 = 4"
" 64/16 = 4"
"
As observed that the quotient is always 4 each time the cubic sum is divided by the sum of cubes, a learner can thus deduce from emerging pattern the relationship and formmulate a rule as such."

"
Note: For a single, specific integer - there exist a relationship between the binomianl sum of its cubes and the cube of its binomial sum, the quotient of which is always a constant number 4. "
"
The general formula , thus, is as follows:"
" x3 + x3 = z"
" (x + x)3 = z"
" (2x)3 = z"
" 8x3 = z"

" 8x3/z = 4 "
"
There exist a relationship between Binomial sum of the first degrees and the first degree of its binomial sum."\n" The quotient of which is unity.

There exist a relationship between Binomial sum of the second degrees and the second degree of its binomial sum."
" The quotient of which is a constant number 2."

"

Note that the rule changes for polynomials of the 1st,2nd,3rd ... nth degrees, and that remains with the aspiring mathematician to further investigate and draw conclusions in form of mathematical formula."\n\n"
There exist a relationship between Binomial sum of its nth degrees and the nth degree of its binomial sum - the quotient of which is n."\n" Verify.

Let us experiment with a set of Prime within range(1,100)."
" The following set is generated as a result: "
" p = {1,2,3,5,7,11,13,17,19,23...}"
" "
" Summing up the double digit prime numbers of p we get:"
" p = {1,2,3,5,7,1 + 1, 1 + 3, 1 + 7,1 + 9, 2 + 3, ...}"
" = {1,2,3,5,7,2,4,8,10,5,...}"
" = {1,2,3,5,7,2,4,8,1 + 0,5,...}"
" = {1,2,3,5,7,2,4,8,1,5} "
" "
" Notice that except for the 3 that comes naturally with the set of primes, the consolodited set bears no 3, 6 and 9 (multiples of 3)"
"
This means that the set of prime numbers within the given range cannot have digitally permuted sums."
"
What conclusion can you draw? "\n" Can you conclude the same for a three digit range(100 - 999) and an up to infinite range? "\n" etc...
